INVESTORS SHUN U.S. AUCTION OF 30-YEAR BONDS

  
 (ATTN: Calif.)   (ART ADV: Graphic is being sent to NYT graphic clients.
Nonsubscribers can make individual purchase by calling 888-603-1036
or 888-346-9867.) 
(rk) 
 By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER   
 c.2000 N.Y. Times News Service    

   NEW YORK _ For several weeks, the Treasury bond market has been
whipsawed by uncertainty associated with the government's plan to
buy back some publicly held long-term debt with the budget surplus.
There have been sharp daily moves, then reversals a day later. And
traders say that they have often been on the wrong side of the
action, causing painful losses for some.

   Thursday, Wall Street dealers and traders indicated that they
had had enough. They shunned the Treasury's auction of $10 billion
in new 30-year bonds, leaving the government with the least demand
ever at such a sale. ``People didn't want the risk of participating
because they didn't know where it would come out,'' said Louis
Crandall, chief economist at R.H. Wrightson Associates.

   Those results, and growing frustration over the signals from the
Treasury _ even though some have been misinterpreted _ sent
Treasury prices tumbling while yields, which move in the opposite
direction, shot higher.

   In recent weeks, the yield on the 30-year bond, which is usually
higher than that on short-term securities to entice investors, has
fallen below that of the two-year note. Then Thursday the spread
between the yield on the two-year note and the 30-year bond
narrowed sharply, giving the bond market another sudden jolt.

   The yield on the new 30-year bond, which was auctioned at 6.34
percent, finished at 6.32 percent, well up from the 6.17 percent
Wednesday in the so-called when-issued market. The yield on the old
30-year bond jumped to 6.42 percent from 6.31 percent, while the
price fell 1 12/32 to 96 1/32.

   The yield on the two-year note rose to 6.65 percent from 6.63
percent Wednesday. On Tuesday, the yield on the two-year note was
6.67 percent, while the yield on the new 30-year bond was 6.10
percent, a spread of just over half a percentage point. That spread
has now narrowed to a third of a percentage point.

   These swift and costly swings are the result of the distortions
that have occurred in the market since the Treasury confirmed on
Jan. 13 that it would be buying back longer-term debt. The yield on
the 10-year note has also been distorted as Wall Street firms
indicated that it would replace the 30-year bond as the market
benchmark.

   The distortions were exacerbated last Wednesday, when a few more
details about the buybacks were announced along with the news that
the amount of the the new 30-year bond offering, being sold
Thursday and in May, would be much smaller than expected. The
prospect of limited supply led to panic buying last Thursday. As
the price rose, the yield on the 30-year bond fell to 6.13 percent,
from 6.28 percent Wednesday and then jumped back up to 6.26 percent
on Friday.

   Dealers say these swings produced big losses but no one is
owning up to them so far.

   Before a Treasury auction, dealers on Wall Street usually go
short on the issue to be sold _ that is, in this case, they sell
30-year bonds they own to make room for the ones they expect to buy
when they bid in the auction. This assures that they do not wind up
with more than they want.

   But because so many dealers wanted nothing to do with the new
30-year bond, they did not go short ahead of the auction, traders
said. They then made very weak bids in the auction, leaving the
bonds to insurance companies and pension funds that need them for
investing and money management purposes.

   This meant that the new bond's yield soared. Just before the
bidding closed, the yield in the when-issued market was 6.24
percent and the yield of the auction was 6.34 percent.

   ``People didn't feel confident going short,'' said Charles
Parkhurst, managing director for government bond trading at Salomon
Smith Barney, explaining that dealers just did not want to risk
being short 30-year bonds if the price suddenly took off again and
did not want the new bond either.

   N. Graham Allen, managing director for global fixed income at
Wells Capital Management in Los Angeles, said he was not interested
in the new 30-year bond because the trading distortions had sent
the yield down too low and ``we couldn't see what was going to
maintain that.''

   Adding to the confusion Thursday were comments made on Wednesday
by Treasury Secretary Lawrence Summers. Many investors took his
remarks as a signal that the Treasury would also buy back
shorter-term securities, leaving many investors to conclude that
the 30-year bond was not so special after all. Although the
Treasury indicated this interpretation was wrong and that the
buybacks would be of long-term securities, investors sold the
30-year bond Wednesday, pushing the yield higher.

   But the flight from the 30-year bond may not be so bad. Crandall
said the two-day selloff was unwinding some of the distortions that
had racked the bond market.
